message_1: A beam of unpolarized light with an intensity of 10 W/m² passes through a polarizing filter that allows only 50% of the light to pass through. What is the intensity of the resulting polarized light?
message_2:
When unpolarized light passes through a polarizing filter, the intensity of the resulting polarized light is reduced by a factor of the percentage of light allowed to pass through. In this case, the polarizing filter allows 50% of the light to pass through.

To find the intensity of the resulting polarized light, multiply the initial intensity by the percentage of light allowed to pass through:

Intensity of polarized light = Initial intensity × Percentage of light allowed to pass through

Intensity of polarized light = 10 W/m² × 0.50

Intensity of polarized light = 5 W/m²

So, the intensity of the resulting polarized light is 5 W/m².
